linkedinPersonalTeaser:
I've been watching the AI agent wars unfold this week. Amazon expanded Rufus. OpenAI added checkout to ChatGPT. Hotels are deploying concierge robots.

Everyone's building agents. Almost nobody's asking: do consumers actually want them?

Here's the uncomfortable number: only one third of consumers say they'd complete a purchase through an AI agent. Not because the technology doesn't work. Because our brains are wired to look for trust signals that agents can't show.

When an AI recommends something, where's the social proof? Where's the "people like you bought this"? The agent might have processed millions of data points. But if it can't show its work, your brain treats that absence as a red flag.

The companies that figure this out will use AI to scale research while preserving human touchpoints for trust.

But here's my question: are you building agents that replace human judgment, or tools that amplify it?
